title: How to Create a Variable in Java

steps.headline: Create a simple Java program.
Scroll to a place where you want to insert the variable.
steps.description:
Remember: If you place a variable in the main class, you can reference it anywhere. Choose the type of variable you need. Integer data types : Used to store integer values like 3, 4, -34 etc
byte
short
int
long


Floating Point data type : Used to store numbers having fractional part like 3.479
float
double


Character data type: Used to store characters like 's', 'r', 'g', 'f' etc
char


Boolean data types : Can store either of the two values: true and false
boolean


Reference data types : Used to store references to objects
Array types
Object types like String

steps.headline: Create the variable.
Protect variables from being edited later, optionally, by adding "final type name" between the parentheses in the second line of your code (public static void main).
steps.description: final int someNumber = 35;  Adding the 'final' here means that the variable 'someNumber' cannot be changed later

tyn: JDK. This task is so simple that any version is suitable.
A text editor that can save the text in 'plain text' format.
An IDE like NetBeans to make things easier.
sentences: "); Scroll to a place where you want to insert the variable.
Remember: If you place a variable in the main class, you can reference it anywhere.
Choose the type of variable you need.

Integer data types : Used to store integer values like 3, 4, -34 etc
byte
short
int
long


Floating Point data type : Used to store numbers having fractional part like 3.479
float
double


Character data type: Used to store characters like 's', 'r', 'g', 'f' etc
char


Boolean data types : Can store either of the two values: true and false
boolean


Reference data types : Used to store references to objects
Array types
Object types like String Create the variable.
Here are examples of how to create and assign a value to each type.

"} Understand how this works.
Protect variables from being edited later, optionally, by adding "final type name" between the parentheses in the second line of your code (public static void main).
final int someNumber = 35;  Adding the 'final' here means that the variable 'someNumber' cannot be changed later
